cmCourseInfo.description: An introductory course that explores the development, physiology and continually changing function of the nervous system as it relates to certain types of human behaviour. Critical analysis of scientific evidence is used to enrich learning.
cmCourseInfo.title: Introduction to Neuroscience

breadthTypes.description: BR=4 Living Things and Their Environment

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
This is an online synchronous course.
Lectures and tutorials will be fully online via live webinar (using Blackboard Collaborate Ultra – accessed within Quercus) on Tuesdays and Thursdays 10am to 1pm (Eastern Time).
Lectures and tutorials will be recorded for asynchronous viewing, but it is strongly recommended that all students “attend” online all lectures and tutorials.

cmCourseInfo.description: An introductory course in Health and Disease using an interdisciplinary approach that integrates bacteriology and virology with other aspects of human biology, including chronic disease and neoplasia. An exploration of the key concepts and approaches that are necessary for understanding the dynamic nexus of human health and disease. (Lab Fees: $40)
cmCourseInfo.title: Introduction to Health and Disease

breadthTypes.description: BR=4 Living Things and Their Environment

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
This is an online, hybrid delivery course. Lectures will be given as 2-hr online videos/week asynchronously. Tutorials will be synchronous for one hour per week. Students will have the opportunity for synchronous online office hour 1 hrs/week to ask questions and clarifications about lecture content. Students will need access to PDF, PowerPoint and the ability to use blackboard collaborate for webinars.

cmCourseInfo.description: An introduction to classical and modern methods of genetic analysis. Topics include Mendelian genetics, the genetics of human population and disease, genomics, and applications of genetics to human society.
cmCourseInfo.title: General & Human Genetics

breadthTypes.description: BR=4 Living Things and Their Environment

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
This is an online, synchronous (live) course. Lectures are synchronous (live with the professor and TAs) on Tuesdays and Thursdays from 6:00pm to 8:00pm via Blackboard Collaborate. Lecture recordings consisting of voiced-over PowerPoint presentations will also be posted on Quercus. Tutorials are synchronous, live with the TAs, on Tuesdays and Thursdays from 8:00pm to 9:00pm via Blackboard Collaborate. Tutorial quizzes: synchronous, during the normal tutorial time. There will be 2 timed exams, during the normal lecture time, and Proctor U will be used.

cmCourseInfo.description: This neuroscience course focuses on higher brain functions and the mechanisms underlying human and animal behaviours. Topics may include the emerging role of the gut microbiome's impact on behaviour, pathogens that alter neuronal development and the biological basis of mindfulness and placebos. In addition, the impact that exercise and sleep play in modulating these behaviours are examined. Common experimental techniques used in neuroscience research such as brain imaging and cellular genetics are emphasized.
cmCourseInfo.title: Neurobiology of Behaviour

breadthTypes.description: BR=4 Living Things and Their Environment

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
This is an online, asynchronous course. Lectures and tutorials will be given as 2-3hr online videos/week asynchronously. Students will have the opportunity for synchronous online webinar class 1-2hrs/week to ask questions and clarifications about lecture and tutorial content. Students will need access to PDF, Power Point and the ability to use Microsoft Office Teams for webinars.

cmCourseInfo.description: Laboratory and lecture course studying the structure of the cell, various tissues and organ systems. Emphasis is on functional morphology and the adaptive response (including the inflammatory reaction) by comparing histological sections of normal tissues and organs with common diseases including neoplasia, respiratory, and liver disease. (Lab Materials Fee: $27)
cmCourseInfo.title: Vertebrate Histology and Histopathology

breadthTypes.description: BR=4 Living Things and Their Environment

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
This is an online, hybrid delivery course. Lectures are asynchronous, voiced-over PowerPoint presentations posted on Quercus. Tutorials are synchronous, Wednesdays and Fridays from 1:00pm to 3:00pm via Blackboard Collaborate. Live with the TAs and prof! Bell-Ringer Tests: synchronous, during their normal tutorial time.¾ There will be 2 timed exams.

cmCourseInfo.description: Advancing technology increases our ability to intervene in the course of natural events involving human health and well being. Questions arise as whether we ought to and who will benefit or be harmed.  This course considers the far-reaching bioethical implications of emerging bio-technology. Topics to be explored include-but are not limited to- ethical considerations in emerging reproductive technologies, genetic alteration/genetic enhancement. Use of life support technologies, synthetic life, life extension.
cmCourseInfo.title: Ethical Considerations in Emerging Technology

breadthTypes.description: BR=4 Living Things and Their Environment

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
This is an online course.

cmCourseInfo.description: Explore the scientific basis and interdisciplinary healthcare practices of several diseases (diseases vary by year). Discuss current issues related to the biology and the impact of these diseases.
cmCourseInfo.title: Topics in Health & Disease
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: 9 FCE complete,  HMB202H1/ HMB203H1/ HMB204H1, BIO230H1/BIO255H1, PSL300H1

breadthTypes.description: BR=4 Living Things and Their Environment

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
This is an online, asynchronous course. Lectures and tutorials will be given as 2-3hr online videos/week asynchronously. Students will have the opportunity for synchronous online webinar class 1-2hrs/week to ask questions and clarifications about lecture and tutorial content. Students will need access to PDF, Power Point and the ability to use Microsoft Office Teams for webinars.

cmCourseInfo.description: This course engages students in the fundamental science of epidemiology applied to health and disease. After an introduction to various measures of health and disease, the scientific methods used to investigate, analyze, prevent and control health problems will be illustrated using biomedical and public health examples.
cmCourseInfo.title: Epidemiology of Health & Disease

breadthTypes.description: BR=4 Living Things and Their Environment

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
This is an online, asynchronous course. Lectures and tutorials will be given as 2-3hr online videos/week asynchronously. Students will have the opportunity for synchronous online office hour 1-2hrs/week to ask questions and clarifications about lecture and tutorial content. Students will need access to PDF, PowerPoint and the ability to use Blackboard Collaborate in the course Quercus interface for webinars.

cmCourseInfo.description: Genetic basis of both the normal and abnormal development of the nervous system and its function. Topics include the regulation of neural gene expression, the role of epigenetics on neuron function, genome wide association studies and disorders of brain and behaviour, optogenetic and pharmacogenetic techniques to probe neural circuit function. Tutorials emphasize critical analysis of primary research.
cmCourseInfo.title: Neurogenomics

breadthTypes.description: BR=4 Living Things and Their Environment

This is an online, asynchronous course. Lectures and tutorials will be given as 2-3hr online videos/week asynchronously. Students will have the opportunity for synchronous online office hour 1-2hrs/week to ask questions and clarifications about lecture and tutorial content. Students will need access to PDF, PowerPoint and the ability to use Blackboard Collaborate for webinars.

courses.name: International Research Project in Human Biology

cmCourseInfo.description: Your individual, independent research project is supervised by a faculty member in an approved university. This unique opportunity to conduct a lab-based research project is open to students in any Human Biology program. Coordinated by Centre for International Experience. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
cmCourseInfo.title: International Research Project in Human Biology
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: At least 8.5 FCEs including relevant courses in human biology.

courses.name: International Research Project in Human Biology

cmCourseInfo.description: Your individual, independent research project is supervised by a faculty member in an approved university. This unique opportunity to conduct a lab-based research project is open to students in any Human Biology program. Not eligible for CR/NCR option. Coordinated by Woodsworth College.
cmCourseInfo.title: International Research Project in Human Biology
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: An approved 300-series science laboratory course and permission of the Human Biology Program from which application forms may be obtained.

courses.name: International Research Project in Human Biology

cmCourseInfo.description: Your individual, independent research project is supervised by a faculty member in an approved university. This unique opportunity to conduct a lab-based research project is open to students in any Human Biology program. Not eligible for CR/NCR option. Coordinated by Woodsworth College.
cmCourseInfo.title: International Research Project in Human Biology
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: An approved 300-series science laboratory course and permission of the Human Biology Program from which application forms may be obtained.

cmCourseInfo.description: This seminar course focuses on recent research into the neurobiology underlying human behaviour. A variety of normal and abnormal human behaviours are studied which may include: voluntary action; moral cognition; hedonism; aggression; mental health; addiction; the impact of the gut microbiome on brain development and health.
cmCourseInfo.title: Seminar in Neurobiology of Behaviour

breadthTypes.description: BR=4 Living Things and Their Environment

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
This is an online, asynchronous course.¾Lectures and tutorials will be given as 2-3hr online videos/week asynchronously. Students will have the opportunity for synchronous online webinar class 1-2hrs/week to ask questions and clarifications about lecture and tutorial content. Students will need access to PDF, Power Point and the ability to use Microsoft Office Teams for webinars. To enrol in this course, please fill out the Request Application Survey found on the HMB website under Current Students, Special Course Enrolment. For questions, please contact hmb.undergrad@utoronto.ca.

sections.name: LEC0101
sections.subTitle: Brain Tumours, Diagnosis to Treatment Effects

cmCourseInfo.description: This course focuses on various medical research related to human disease. Topics vary based on course instructor's area(s) of expertise.
cmCourseInfo.title: Seminar in Health & Disease
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: 14 FCE complete, PSL300H1, PSL301H1, HMB302H1/HMB322H1, and HMB202H1/HMB203H1/HMB204H1

breadthTypes.description: BR=4 Living Things and Their Environment

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
This is an online, asynchronous course. Lectures will be given as two x 2hr online live classes that will be recorded for those who cannot attend live. Student will be required to make one live presentation during the course but can record their presentation ahead of time, if necessary. Students need pdf software and the ability to use Blackboard Collaborate (Ultra). To enrol in this course, please fill out the Request Application Survey found on the HMB website under Current Students, Special Course Enrolment. For questions, please contact hmb.undergrad@utoronto.ca.

courses.name: The Biology of the Human Metallome

cmCourseInfo.description: This course will discuss how heavy metals are integral to organ function through various biological pathways, the importance of metal regulation and control and its relationship with gene transcription. An introduction of metallo-therapeutics will also be featured, ranging from neurodegenerative therapies to cancer treatment.
cmCourseInfo.title: The Biology of the Human Metallome
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: 14 FCE complete, HMB265H1/BIO260H1, BIO230H1/ BIO255H1, BCH210H1

breadthTypes.description: BR=4 Living Things and Their Environment

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
This is an online, asynchronous course. Lectures are recorded. Office hours are live, but discussion board is available for questions. To enrol in this course, please fill out the Request Application Survey found on the HMB website under Current Students, Special Course Enrolment. For questions, please contact hmb.undergrad@utoronto.ca.

cmCourseInfo.description: Proper development of the human brain is essential for human health. This course will examine how neurodevelopment failures contribute to neurological disorders and diseases, such as epilepsy and autism. Current research from basic, translational, and clinical perspectives will be examined using case studies. The impact of neurodevelopmental disorders and diseases on the individual and community will be discussed.
cmCourseInfo.title: Neurodevelopmental Disorders and Diseases

breadthTypes.description: BR=4 Living Things and Their Environment

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
This is an online, asynchronous course. Lectures will be given as two x 2hr online live' classes that will be recorded for those who cannot attend live. Students need pdf software and the ability to use Blackboard Collaborate (Ultra). To enrol in this course, please fill out the Request Application Survey found on the HMB website under Current Students, Special Course Enrolment. For questions, please contact hmb.undergrad@utoronto.ca.

cmCourseInfo.description: Examine the physiological and biochemical responses of the human body to both acute and chronic bouts of physical activity. The impact of activity on health, and health on physical activity, is explored by examining adaptations from the cellular to the systemic level of bodily function.
cmCourseInfo.title: Exercise Physiology

breadthTypes.description: BR=4 Living Things and Their Environment

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
This is an online, mixed delivery course.
Lectures and tutorials will be given live as 2-3hr online videos/week synchronously, but also recorded and posted.
Students will have the opportunity for an optional synchronous online office hour 1-2hrs/week to ask questions and clarifications about lecture and tutorial content.
Students will need access to PDF, PowerPoint and the ability to use Blackboard Collaborate for webinars.
To enrol in this course, please fill out the Request Application Survey found on the HMB website under Current Students, Special Course Enrolment.
For questions, please contact hmb.undergrad@utoronto.ca.

cmCourseInfo.description: A research project course for students enrolled in a Human Biology program, supervised by a faculty member appointed in a faculty or division at St. George Campus (Faculties of Arts & Science, Medicine, Engineering, Dalla Lana School of Public Health, etc.). Open to third and fourth year students. Students are responsible for securing their own supervisor. Should a HMB Specialist require help securing a supervisor, the request must be made by email to the Human Biology Program Office no later than July 20 for Academic year projects and January 30 for Summer projects. Completed applications for this course are due to the Human Biology Program Office by September 1 for Academic year projects and May 1 for Summer projects. Please see the application on the Special Enrolment Courses page on the HMB Website. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
cmCourseInfo.title: Research Project in Human Biology
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: Permission of the Human Biology Program; please refer to the Human Biology Program website for more details
cmCourseInfo.exclusionsText: Students are not permitted to do a HMB research project concurrently with another research project

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
The research project is possible only for remote projects. To enrol in this course, please fill out the Application form found on the HMB website under Current Students, Special Course Enrolment. For questions, please contact hmb.undergrad@utoronto.ca

Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
